title: Report: Axel Springer in talks to buy Business Insider for $560M
text:
Henry Blodget of Business Insider. (Photo: Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY)
1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE German publisher Axel Springer may buy business news site Business Insider for about $560 million “within weeks,” according to Recode.
Axel Springer already owns a minority stake in the news site but is now looking to buy the entire company. In Axel Springer's earlier investment, Business Insider was valued at about $200 million, said the Recode report, written by its media reporter, Peter Kafka. Kafka says he is a shareholder of Business Insider.
In 2013, Business Insider generated about $20 million in revenue. But it had grown 70% last year, the Recode report noted.
To maintain their influence on growing, buzz-generating digital content sites, large publishers and media giants have been investing in the emerging sector in recent months. In August, Comcast's NBCUniversal invested $200 million into BuzzFeed, valuing the news-and-entertainment site at about $1.5 billion. A week earlier, it also invested $200 million into Vox Media, which owns Recode, sports blog network SB Nation and Vox.com.
In March, Walt Disney Co. paid $500 million to buy YouTube network Maker Studios, with a condition to pay more if some growth targets are met.
Axel Springer, which owns German national newspapers Die Welt and Bild, has been in an acquisitive mood . Britain's Pearson had been in talks to sell the Financial Times to Axel Springer before selling the paper to Japanese media group Nikkei for $1.3 billion.
